title: Mind Your Manners
text:
While talking to large language models like ChatGPT, you might wonder: does politeness actually matter? After all, these systems are machines and they don‚Äôt have feelings. They don‚Äôt get annoyed if you forget to say ‚Äúplease‚Äù or ‚Äúthank you.‚Äù However, should we still talk to them as if they were other humans? I am trying to explore if the way you phrase your prompts can sometimes change the quality of the responses you get.



To test this idea, I designed a small experiment. I created pairs of prompts across 3 different common tasks (like summarization, explaining, and brainstorming). Each pair had a blunt version and a polite version.
Let‚Äôs see the results!


summarize these paragraphs in three sentences It‚Äôs Just Adding One Word at a Time That ChatGPT can automatically generate something that reads even superficially like human-written text is remarkable, and unexpected. But how does it do it? And why does it work? My purpose here is to give a rough outline of what‚Äôs going on inside ChatGPT‚Äîand then to explore why it is that it can do so well in producing what we might consider to be meaningful text. I should say at the outset that I‚Äôm going to focus on the big picture of what‚Äôs going on‚Äîand while I‚Äôll mention some engineering details, I won‚Äôt get deeply into them. (And the essence of what I‚Äôll say applies just as well to other current ‚Äúlarge language models‚Äù [LLMs] as to ChatGPT.) The first thing to explain is that what ChatGPT is always fundamentally trying to do is to produce a ‚Äúreasonable continuation‚Äù of whatever text it‚Äôs got so far, where by ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù we mean ‚Äúwhat one might expect someone to write after seeing what people have written on billions of webpages, etc.‚Äù So let‚Äôs say we‚Äôve got the text ‚ÄúThe best thing about AI is its ability to‚Äù. Imagine scanning billions of pages of human-written text (say on the web and in digitized books) and finding all instances of this text‚Äîthen seeing what word comes next what fraction of the time. ChatGPT effectively does something like this, except that (as I‚Äôll explain) it doesn‚Äôt look at literal text; it looks for things that in a certain sense ‚Äúmatch in meaning‚Äù. But the end result is that it produces a ranked list of words that might follow, together with ‚Äúprobabilities‚Äù:



ChatGPT generates text by predicting the most likely continuation of what has been written so far, based on patterns learned from billions of examples of human writing. Rather than copying exact text, it matches meanings and produces a ranked list of possible next words with associated probabilities. Its core function is simply to add one word (or token) at a time in a way that seems reasonable and coherent to readers.

Instead of copying exact sequences, it generates words that ‚Äúmatch in meaning,‚Äù producing text that feels natural and coherent. The result is a ranked list of possible next words with probabilities, allowing it to generate responses that seem meaningful and human-like.



For this summarization task, both responses seem similar in quality although they are different. Maybe for summarization tasks, manners are not necessary.



Explain recursion



Recursion is a programming concept where a function calls itself to solve a problem. Instead of solving the whole problem at once, the function breaks it into smaller subproblems of the same type.
Here‚Äôs the key idea:

Base case ‚Äì a simple situation the function can solve directly, without further recursion (this prevents infinite loops).
Recursive case ‚Äì the function reduces the problem into a smaller version of itself and calls itself again.





The factorial of a number n (written as n!) is:

n! = n √ó (n-1)!
with the base case: 1! = 1.

In code (Python):
def factorial(n):
    if n == 1:  # base case
        return 1
    else:       # recursive case
        return n * factorial(n - 1)
Calling factorial(5) works like this:
factorial(5)
= 5 * factorial(4)
= 5 * (4 * factorial(3))
= 5 * (4 * (3 * factorial(2)))
= 5 * (4 * (3 * (2 * factorial(1))))
= 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1
= 120





It‚Äôs elegant for problems with natural ‚Äúdivide into smaller subproblems‚Äù structures, like:

Tree/graph traversal (exploring branches)
Sorting algorithms (like quicksort, mergesort)
Mathematical sequences (Fibonacci numbers)



üëâ Do you want me to also show you how recursion compares to using a loop (iterative approach), with the same factorial example?



Would you mind explaining recursion to me please? I would really appreciate it.



Of course! Let‚Äôs break recursion down step by step.




Recursion is when a function calls itself as part of its definition. It‚Äôs like saying: to solve this big problem, I‚Äôll solve a smaller version of the same problem, and then use that answer to build up to the final solution.




Every recursive function needs:

Base case ‚Äì a stopping condition that tells the function when to stop calling itself. Without this, it would keep going forever.
Recursive case ‚Äì the part where the function calls itself with a smaller or simpler version of the problem.





Let‚Äôs look at computing a factorial. Factorial of a number n (written n!) means:
\[
n! = n \times (n-1) \times (n-2) \times \dots \times 1
\]
Using recursion:

Base case: 1! = 1
Recursive case: n! = n * (n-1)!

In Python:
def factorial(n):
    if n == 1:  # base case
        return 1
    return n * factorial(n - 1)  # recursive case
So factorial(5) calls:

5 * factorial(4)
5 * (4 * factorial(3))
5 * (4 * (3 * factorial(2)))
5 * (4 * (3 * (2 * factorial(1))))
Base case: factorial(1) = 1

And it works out to 120.




Imagine you have a stack of boxes, each with a note inside:

The top box says: ‚ÄúOpen the next box and multiply its result by 5.‚Äù
The next says: ‚ÄúOpen the next box and multiply its result by 4.‚Äù
This continues until the last box, which just says: ‚ÄúReturn 1.‚Äù

You open the last box, then backtrack through the stack, multiplying as you go.




Recursion is great for problems that:

Have a natural ‚Äúsmaller version‚Äù (like factorial, Fibonacci numbers, or summing a list).
Involve divide and conquer (like quicksort, mergesort, or binary search).
Work with tree- or graph-like structures (like exploring a family tree, filesystem, or solving mazes).


üëâ Would you like me to also show you a visual step-by-step trace of how recursion unfolds (like a diagram of the function calls), or keep it more conceptual?



In my opinion, the response to the polite prompt was much more informative and clear with sections like ‚ÄúEveryday analogy‚Äù. The polite response seemed more structured and was a little friendlier with the ‚ÄúOf course!‚Äù at the beginning. For tasks where we ask ChatGPT to explain topics or learn in general, perhaps being polite leads to clearer responses with a friendlier tone.

AI r√©sum√© + interview coach for job seekers.
B2B SaaS for managing fractional workers/freelancer collectives.
Automatic meeting summarization + follow-up task generation.
Learning platforms tailored to upskilling older workers for AI age.

Interactive fitness games with AR/VR.
Fan-generated content monetization platforms for sports/music.
Streaming service that curates based on mood + biofeedback.
Digital time capsules (NFT-backed or not) for personal/family memories.






Space debris tracking + insurance.
Personalized education tutors powered by open-source LLMs.
Biofabricated materials for construction (fungi-based bricks, etc.).
Robotics-as-a-service for small warehouses.
Quantum-safe encryption for SMEs.


üëâ Would you like me to filter these ideas for feasibility/low startup cost (good for students/first-time founders), or should I expand into bolder, long-term moonshots?



I would be grateful if you could share some startups ideas that you have. Anything would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!



Of course! Here are some startup ideas across different spaces ‚Äî some realistic and near-term, and others a bit more futuristic to spark imagination:





Carbon Footprint Companion: An AI-powered app that automatically calculates your personal or household carbon footprint based on receipts, emails, and travel data, then suggests actionable ways to offset it.
Micro-Local Recycling: A service that matches people with recyclable items (e.g., electronics, batteries) to neighbors or micro-collectors, reducing waste and creating small-scale recycling jobs.
Climate Risk Insurance: Affordable insurance packages tailored for individuals or small businesses exposed to floods, heatwaves, or wildfires, backed by AI-driven climate models.






Personal AI Memory: A secure AI tool that remembers everything you read, write, and hear across your devices, then retrieves info on request (a ‚Äúsecond brain‚Äù you can query).
AI Tutor Marketplace: Specialized tutoring AIs for niche subjects (e.g., organic chemistry, legal writing, SAT prep), trained on best practices and available 24/7.
Meeting ‚Üí Action Pipeline: A startup that takes in recordings/notes, extracts action items, auto-assigns tasks into project management tools, and tracks completion.






Sleep-Friendly Social Media: A mobile app that only delivers content aligned with better sleep hygiene ‚Äî no blue light after 10pm, positive-only posts, guided wind-down routines.
Loneliness Reduction Network: A platform pairing older adults with vetted companions for shared virtual or in-person activities, with gamified points for participants.
AI Nutritionist: Snap a photo of your meal, get instant nutritional breakdowns, and receive daily adjustment suggestions for health goals.






Pop-Up Co-Living Spaces: Short-term, themed communal housing (e.g., ‚Äúwriters‚Äô retreat,‚Äù ‚Äúremote workers by the beach‚Äù), bookable for weeks at a time with built-in community events.
Personalized Adventure Generator: An app that creates hyper-local micro-adventures (e.g., ‚Äútoday: hidden park + taco stand + mural walk‚Äù), personalized to your interests and mood.
Zero-Wait Restaurants: A restaurant network with pre-order-only dining ‚Äî all meals ready exactly when you arrive.






Dream Recorder: A startup working on wearable sleep headbands that record dream activity and reconstruct narratives (starting with text, eventually visuals).
On-Demand Personal Robotics: Subscription service where a modular household robot arrives to clean, assemble furniture, or run errands, then leaves.
AI-Powered Court Companion: For people who can‚Äôt afford lawyers ‚Äî real-time guidance in small claims or traffic court, with explanations of rights and next steps.


Would you like me to narrow these down into more practical startup ideas you could actually launch as a student or solo founder, or should I keep them in this broad, exploratory style?



I found the polite response more useful for this task because it provided descriptions of each idea instead of just the title of the idea. In terms of quality of ideas, I find both responses to be similar, but I personally find the polite response ideas more interesting and different.




Based on these experiments, I believe that being polite to ChatGPT can be helpful at times and give you better responses, especially for tasks that could have more variation. For example, there are not too many different ways to summarize a text and still get all the information. However, for explaining and brainstorming, there are many different ways that ChatGPT could respond.

title: What animal do I look like?
text:
After classes, my friend and I were at a cafe and we were trying to figure out what animals we look like. Long story short, this idea spawned because she was drawing cartoons of animal versions of us.
She had been told that she looked like a deer and I had been told that I look like a cat. We could see each other looking like both of these animals, but we wanted another opinion. There was no one else we could ask, but then we realized that we could ask ChatGPT!

Prompt: Can you make a cartoon animal with characteristics like this face?



ChatGPT response


She became a deer, just like what she was told!
This made us realize maybe we do actually look like these animals‚Ä¶ I found it very interesting that ChatGPT was not able to directly turn photos of people into animals, but with different prompting we were able to get the results we wanted. I am more curious about the restrictions and limitations of ChatGPT.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
